For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: âˆ€ (n : â„•), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "âˆ€ n âˆˆ â„•, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

type: âˆ€ (n : â„•), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "âˆ€ n âˆˆ â„•, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

type: âˆ€ (n : â„•), Even n âˆ¨ Odd n
name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

The theorem `Nat.even_pow` states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, the statement "The number `m` raised to the power `n` is even" is equivalent to the statement "The number `m` is even and `n` is not zero". Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers (in other words, it is a multiple of 2).

type: âˆ€ {m n : â„•}, Even (m ^ n) â†” Even m âˆ§ n â‰  0
name: Nat.even_pow
docString: The theorem `Nat.even_pow` states that for any two natural numbers `m` and `n`, the statement "The number `m` raised to the power `n` is even" is equivalent to the statement "The number `m` is even and `n` is not zero". Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers (in other words, it is a multiple of 2).

The product of two natural numbers is greater than 1 if and only if
at least one of them is greater than 1 and both are positive.

name: Nat.one_lt_mul_iff
docString:
The product of two natural numbers is greater than 1 if and only if
at least one of them is greater than 1 and both are positive.
